sentences: Kyrre Gørvell-Dahll (born 11 September 1991), better known by his stage name Kygo (Norwegian: [ˈkỳːɡuː]), is a Norwegian DJ, songwriter and record producer.
section: N/A

sentences: He garnered international attention with his December 2013 remix of the track "I See Fire" by Ed Sheeran and his December 2014 single "Firestone" featuring Conrad Sewell.
section: N/A

sentences: In late 2015, he became the fastest artist to reach 1 billion streams on Spotify, and by June 2016, he had reached 2 billion streams on Spotify.
section: N/A

sentences: Kygo has since released several singles, such as "Stole the Show", "Here for You" and "Stay" in 2015, "It Ain't Me" in 2017 and a 2019 remix of "Higher Love" performed by Whitney Houston, all of which have debuted on several international charts.
section: N/A

sentences: His debut album, Cloud Nine, was released on 13 May 2016.
section: N/A

sentences: Kygo became the first house music producer to perform at an Olympics closing ceremony on 21 August 2016 at the 2016 Rio Olympics.
section: N/A

sentences: In March 2018, Billboard ranked Kygo 3rd on its 2018 ranking of dance musicians titled Billboard Dance 100.
section: N/A

sentences: In 2018, he was ranked 32 on DJ Mag's top 100 DJs of the world, and in October 2019 he was ranked 42.

== Early life ==

sentences: Early life ==
section: == Early life ==

sentences: Kygo was born on 11 September 1991 in Singapore to Norwegian parents and raised in Tønsberg.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: He is the son of Kjersti Gjerde, a dentist in Norway, and Lars Gørvell-Dahll, who was working abroad in the maritime industry.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: He has an older stepbrother Mads, two older sisters Johanne and Jenny, and a younger half-brother Sondre.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: Throughout his childhood, he lived and travelled with his family in Brazil, Japan, Kenya and Egypt.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: Kygo started taking piano lessons at the age of six and considers himself more of a pianist than a disc jockey.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: He stopped when he was 15 or 16 and started producing music with Logic Studio and a MIDI keyboard while watching several tutorials on YouTube.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: When he decided to pursue music full-time, he was halfway through a degree in business and finance at Heriot-Watt University in Edinburgh, Scotland.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: He has cited Swedish DJ Avicii as his main inspiration.
section: == Early life ==
== Career ==

sentences: Career ==
section: == Career ==
== Career == | === 2014: Breakthrough ===
== Career == | === 2014: Breakthrough ===

sentences: Breakthrough ===
section: == Career == | === 2014: Breakthrough ===

sentences: On 15 May 2013, Kygo released his first single called "Epsilon" on the Romanian record label Ensis Records.
section: == Career == | === 2014: Breakthrough ===

sentences: On 1 December 2014, he released the single "Firestone", featuring vocals from Conrad Sewell, which gained international recognition and debuted on several charts worldwide, being streamed 700 million times on YouTube and 715 million times on Spotify, as of 2 January 2020.
section: == Career == | === 2014: Breakthrough ===

sentences: After receiving over 80 million views on YouTube and SoundCloud, Kygo was contacted by Avicii and by Chris Martin of Coldplay to create a remix of the song "Midnight".
section: == Career == | === 2014: Breakthrough ===

sentences: He has also supported Avicii at Findings Festival in Oslo, Norway, in 2014.
section: == Career == | === 2014: Breakthrough ===

sentences: On 19 September 2014, it was confirmed that Kygo was to replace Avicii at mainstage in Tomorrowland, due to Avicii's health concerns.
section: == Career == | === 2014: Breakthrough ===

sentences: He was also featured in an interview for Billboard magazine, where he talked to writer Matt Medved about his remixes for Diplo and Coldplay, and talked about his upcoming tour in North America.
section: == Career == | === 2014: Breakthrough ===

sentences: In July 2014, Kygo entered into a partnership with EDM lifestyle brand Electric Family to produce a collaboration bracelet for which one hundred per cent of the proceeds are donated to Médecins Sans Frontières.
section: == Career == | === 2014: Breakthrough ===

sentences: In the same month, he signed a record label deal with Sony International and Ultra Music.
section: == Career == | === 2014: Breakthrough ===
== Career == | === 2015–2016: Cloud Nine and Kygo Life ===

sentences: 2015–2016: Cloud Nine and Kygo Life ===
section: == Career == | === 2015–2016: Cloud Nine and Kygo Life ===

sentences: In February 2015, Kygo's song "ID" was featured in the official trailer for Ultra Music Festival.
section: == Career == | === 2015–2016: Cloud Nine and Kygo Life ===

sentences: The same track is also featured on FIFA 16, a popular association football video game by EA Sports.
section: == Career == | === 2015–2016: Cloud Nine and Kygo Life ===

sentences: On 21 March 2015, he released his second single, titled "Stole the Show", featuring Parson James, which as of 2 January 2019, had 326 million views on YouTube.
section: == Career == | === 2015–2016: Cloud Nine and Kygo Life ===

sentences: On 31 July 2015, he released his third single, "Nothing Left", featuring Will Heard.
section: == Career == | === 2015–2016: Cloud Nine and Kygo Life ===

sentences: "Nothing Left" reached number one on the Norwegian Singles Chart.
section: == Career == | === 2015–2016: Cloud Nine and Kygo Life ===

sentences: In August 2015, Kygo was a featured headliner at Lollapalooza in Chicago, one of the biggest music festivals in the world.
section: == Career == | === 2015–2016: Cloud Nine and Kygo Life ===

sentences: On 4 September 2015, he released his fourth single, titled "Here for You", featuring Ella Henderson, which was revealed to be the vocal version of the song "ID" that was released as part of the Ultra Music Festival.
section: == Career == | === 2015–2016: Cloud Nine and Kygo Life ===

sentences: He made his U.S. television debut on The Late Late Show with James Corden in October 2015.
section: == Career == | === 2015–2016: Cloud Nine and Kygo Life ===

sentences: Three months later, his fifth single, "Stay", produced with fellow Norwegian record producer William Larsen and featuring vocals by Maty Noyes, was released on 4 December 2015.
section: == Career == | === 2015–2016: Cloud Nine and Kygo Life ===

sentences: In December 2015, Kygo became the fastest artist in history to reach one billion streams on Spotify.
section: == Career == | === 2015–2016: Cloud Nine and Kygo Life ===

sentences: After the release of the single, Kygo announced that he was embarking on a worldwide tour to promote his debut studio album.
section: == Career == | === 2015–2016: Cloud Nine and Kygo Life ===

sentences: Soon after, he revealed that his debut studio album was going to be released on 19 February 2016, but was delayed.
section: == Career == | === 2015–2016: Cloud Nine and Kygo Life ===

sentences: He, instead, released a teaser of the songs that he was working on that were on his debut studio album and released it on SoundCloud.
section: == Career == | === 2015–2016: Cloud Nine and Kygo Life ===

sentences: In the beginning of March 2016, Kygo announced that his debut studio album was going to be released on 13 May 2016, under the title Cloud Nine.
section: == Career == | === 2015–2016: Cloud Nine and Kygo Life ===

sentences: He also announced that he would be releasing three promotional singles, leading up to the release of the album.
section: == Career == | === 2015–2016: Cloud Nine and Kygo Life ===

sentences: The first of these singles, which was released 18 March 2016, was entitled "Fragile", which features vocals and was collaborated with Labrinth.
section: == Career == | === 2015–2016: Cloud Nine and Kygo Life ===

sentences: The second single came out on 1 April 2016 and was called "Raging", which features vocals from the Irish band Kodaline and was also co-written by James Bay.
section: == Career == | === 2015–2016: Cloud Nine and Kygo Life ===

sentences: The third and last single was released on 22 April 2016 and was entitled "I'm In Love", featuring vocals from James Vincent McMorrow.
section: == Career == | === 2015–2016: Cloud Nine and Kygo Life ===

sentences: Kygo's debut studio album was released on 13 May 2016.
section: == Career == | === 2015–2016: Cloud Nine and Kygo Life ===

sentences: Other collaborations were revealed to include Parson James, Tom Odell, Kodaline, Conrad Sewell, John Legend, James Vincent McMorrow, Foxes, Rhodes, Matt Corby, Maty Noyes, Julia Michaels and Angus & Julia Stone.
section: == Career == | === 2015–2016: Cloud Nine and Kygo Life ===

sentences: Kygo launched a new lifestyle brand called Kygo Life on 17 August 2016.
section: == Career == | === 2015–2016: Cloud Nine and Kygo Life ===

sentences: The brand consists of two collections of high-fashion and relaxed wear, in addition to hardware such as headphones.
section: == Career == | === 2015–2016: Cloud Nine and Kygo Life ===

sentences: Kygo Life is at the moment only available in Europe, the United States and Canada.
section: == Career == | === 2015–2016: Cloud Nine and Kygo Life ===

sentences: He performed "Carry Me" with American singer and songwriter Julia Michaels at the closing ceremony of the 2016 Summer Olympics on 21 August at the Maracanã Stadium in Rio de Janeiro, as part of a segment that promoted the new Olympic Channel service launching after the Games.
